lines.text: Enter BRUTUS and CASSIUS

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: That you have wrong'd me doth appear in this: You have condemn'd and noted Lucius Pella For taking bribes here of the Sardians; Wherein my letters, praying on his side, Because I knew the man, were slighted off.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: You wronged yourself to write in such a case.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: In such a time as this it is not meet That every nice offence should bear his comment.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Let me tell you, Cassius, you yourself Are much condemn'd to have an itching palm; To sell and mart your offices for gold To undeservers.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: I an itching palm! You know that you are Brutus that speak this, Or, by the gods, this speech were else your last.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: The name of Cassius honours this corruption, And chastisement doth therefore hide his head.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Chastisement!

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Remember March, the ides of March remember: Did not great Julius bleed for justice' sake? What villain touch'd his body, that did stab, And not for justice? What, shall one of us That struck the foremost man of all this world But for supporting robbers, shall we now Contaminate our fingers with base bribes, And sell the mighty space of our large honours For so much trash as may be grasped thus? I had rather be a dog, and bay the moon, Than such a Roman.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Brutus, bay not me; I'll not endure it: you forget yourself, To hedge me in; I am a soldier, I, Older in practise, abler than yourself To make conditions.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Go to; you are not, Cassius.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: I am.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: I say you are not.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Urge me no more, I shall forget myself; Have mind upon your health, tempt me no further.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Away, slight man!

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Is't possible?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Hear me, for I will speak. Must I give way and room to your rash choler? Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: O ye gods, ye gods! must I endure all this?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: All this! ay, more: fret till your proud heart break; Go show your slaves how choleric you are, And make your bondmen tremble. Must I budge? Must I observe you? must I stand and crouch Under your testy humour? By the gods You shall digest the venom of your spleen, Though it do split you; for, from this day forth, I'll use you for my mirth, yea, for my laughter, When you are waspish.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Is it come to this?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: You say you are a better soldier: Let it appear so; make your vaunting true, And it shall please me well: for mine own part, I shall be glad to learn of noble men.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: You wrong me every way; you wrong me, Brutus; I said, an elder soldier, not a better: Did I say 'better'?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: If you did, I care not.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: When Caesar lived, he durst not thus have moved me.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Peace, peace! you durst not so have tempted him.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: I durst not!

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: What, durst not tempt him!

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: For your life you durst not!

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Do not presume too much upon my love; I may do that I shall be sorry for.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: You have done that you should be sorry for. There is no terror, Cassius, in your threats, For I am arm'd so strong in honesty That they pass by me as the idle wind, Which I respect not. I did send to you For certain sums of gold, which you denied me: For I can raise no money by vile means: By heaven, I had rather coin my heart, And drop my blood for drachmas, than to wring From the hard hands of peasants their vile trash By any indirection: I did send To you for gold to pay my legions, Which you denied me: was that done like Cassius? Should I have answer'd Caius Cassius so? When Marcus Brutus grows so covetous, To lock such rascal counters from his friends, Be ready, gods, with all your thunderbolts; Dash him to pieces!

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: I denied you not.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: You did.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: I did not: he was but a fool that brought My answer back. Brutus hath rived my heart: A friend should bear his friend's infirmities, But Brutus makes mine greater than they are.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: I do not, till you practise them on me.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: You love me not.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: I do not like your faults.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: A friendly eye could never see such faults.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: A flatterer's would not, though they do appear As huge as high Olympus.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Come, Antony, and young Octavius, come, Revenge yourselves alone on Cassius, For Cassius is aweary of the world; Hated by one he loves; braved by his brother; Cheque'd like a bondman; all his faults observed, Set in a note-book, learn'd, and conn'd by rote, To cast into my teeth. O, I could weep My spirit from mine eyes! There is my dagger, And here my naked breast; within, a heart Dearer than Plutus' mine, richer than gold: If that thou be'st a Roman, take it forth; I, that denied thee gold, will give my heart: Strike, as thou didst at Caesar; for, I know, When thou didst hate him worst, thou lovedst him better Than ever thou lovedst Cassius.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Sheathe your dagger: Be angry when you will, it shall have scope; Do what you will, dishonour shall be humour. O Cassius, you are yoked with a lamb That carries anger as the flint bears fire; Who, much enforced, shows a hasty spark, And straight is cold again.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Hath Cassius lived To be but mirth and laughter to his Brutus, When grief, and blood ill-temper'd, vexeth him?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: When I spoke that, I was ill-temper'd too.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Do you confess so much? Give me your hand.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: And my heart too.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: O Brutus!

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: What's the matter?

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Have not you love enough to bear with me, When that rash humour which my mother gave me Makes me forgetful?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Yes, Cassius; and, from henceforth, When you are over-earnest with your Brutus, He'll think your mother chides, and leave you so.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: [Within]  Let me go in to see the generals; There is some grudge between 'em, 'tis not meet They be alone.

lines.speaker: lucilius
lines.text: [Within]  You shall not come to them.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: [Within]  Nothing but death shall stay me.
Enter Poet, followed by LUCILIUS, TITINIUS, and LUCIUS

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: How now! what's the matter?

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: For shame, you generals! what do you mean? Love, and be friends, as two such men should be; For I have seen more years, I'm sure, than ye.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Ha, ha! how vilely doth this cynic rhyme!

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Get you hence, sirrah; saucy fellow, hence!

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Bear with him, Brutus; 'tis his fashion.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: I'll know his humour, when he knows his time: What should the wars do with these jigging fools? Companion, hence!

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Away, away, be gone.
Exit Poet

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Lucilius and Titinius, bid the commanders Prepare to lodge their companies to-night.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: And come yourselves, and bring Messala with you Immediately to us.
Exeunt LUCILIUS and TITINIUS

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Lucius, a bowl of wine!
Exit LUCIUS

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: I did not think you could have been so angry.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: O Cassius, I am sick of many griefs.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Of your philosophy you make no use, If you give place to accidental evils.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: No man bears sorrow better. Portia is dead.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Ha! Portia!

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: She is dead.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: How 'scaped I killing when I cross'd you so? O insupportable and touching loss! Upon what sickness?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Impatient of my absence, And grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony Have made themselves so strong:--for with her death That tidings came;--with this she fell distract, And, her attendants absent, swallow'd fire.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: And died so?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Even so.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: O ye immortal gods!
Re-enter LUCIUS, with wine and taper

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Speak no more of her. Give me a bowl of wine. In this I bury all unkindness, Cassius.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge. Fill, Lucius, till the wine o'erswell the cup; I cannot drink too much of Brutus' love.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Come in, Titinius! Welcome, good Messala. Now sit we close about this taper here, And call in question our necessities.
Exit LUCIUS
Re-enter TITINIUS, with MESSALA

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Portia, art thou gone?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: No more, I pray you. Messala, I have here received letters, That young Octavius and Mark Antony Come down upon us with a mighty power, Bending their expedition toward Philippi.

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: Myself have letters of the selfsame tenor.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: With what addition?

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: That by proscription and bills of outlawry, Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus, Have put to death an hundred senators.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Therein our letters do not well agree; Mine speak of seventy senators that died By their proscriptions, Cicero being one.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Cicero one!

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: Cicero is dead, And by that order of proscription. Had you your letters from your wife, my lord?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: No, Messala.

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: Nor nothing in your letters writ of her?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Nothing, Messala.

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: That, methinks, is strange.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Why ask you? hear you aught of her in yours?

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: No, my lord.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Now, as you are a Roman, tell me true.

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: Then like a Roman bear the truth I tell: For certain she is dead, and by strange manner.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Why, farewell, Portia. We must die, Messala: With meditating that she must die once, I have the patience to endure it now.

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: Even so great men great losses should endure.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: I have as much of this in art as you, But yet my nature could not bear it so.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Well, to our work alive. What do you think Of marching to Philippi presently?

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: I do not think it good.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Your reason?

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: This it is: 'Tis better that the enemy seek us: So shall he waste his means, weary his soldiers, Doing himself offence; whilst we, lying still, Are full of rest, defense, and nimbleness.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Good reasons must, of force, give place to better. The people 'twixt Philippi and this ground Do stand but in a forced affection; For they have grudged us contribution: The enemy, marching along by them, By them shall make a fuller number up, Come on refresh'd, new-added, and encouraged; From which advantage shall we cut him off, If at Philippi we do face him there, These people at our back.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Hear me, good brother.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Under your pardon. You must note beside, That we have tried the utmost of our friends, Our legions are brim-full, our cause is ripe: The enemy increaseth every day; We, at the height, are ready to decline. There is a tide in the affairs of men, Which, taken at the flood, leads on to fortune; Omitted, all the voyage of their life Is bound in shallows and in miseries. On such a full sea are we now afloat; And we must take the current when it serves, Or lose our ventures.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Then, with your will, go on; We'll along ourselves, and meet them at Philippi.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: The deep of night is crept upon our talk, And nature must obey necessity; Which we will niggard with a little rest. There is no more to say?

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: No more. Good night: Early to-morrow will we rise, and hence.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Lucius! My gown. Farewell, good Messala: Good night, Titinius. Noble, noble Cassius, Good night, and good repose.
Enter LUCIUS
Exit LUCIUS

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: O my dear brother! This was an ill beginning of the night: Never come such division 'tween our souls! Let it not, Brutus.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Every thing is well.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Good night, my lord.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Good night, good brother.

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: Good night, Lord Brutus.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Farewell, every one. Give me the gown. Where is thy instrument?
Exeunt all but BRUTUS
Re-enter LUCIUS, with the gown

lines.speaker: lucius
lines.text: Here in the tent.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: What, thou speak'st drowsily? Poor knave, I blame thee not; thou art o'er-watch'd. Call Claudius and some other of my men: I'll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.

lines.speaker: lucius
lines.text: Varro and Claudius!
Enter VARRO and CLAUDIUS

lines.speaker: varro
lines.text: Calls my lord?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: I pray you, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep; It may be I shall raise you by and by On business to my brother Cassius.

lines.speaker: varro
lines.text: So please you, we will stand and watch your pleasure.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: I will not have it so: lie down, good sirs; It may be I shall otherwise bethink me. Look, Lucius, here's the book I sought for so; I put it in the pocket of my gown.
VARRO and CLAUDIUS lie down

lines.speaker: lucius
lines.text: I was sure your lordship did not give it me.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Bear with me, good boy, I am much forgetful. Canst thou hold up thy heavy eyes awhile, And touch thy instrument a strain or two?

lines.speaker: lucius
lines.text: Ay, my lord, an't please you.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: It does, my boy: I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.

lines.speaker: lucius
lines.text: It is my duty, sir.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: I should not urge thy duty past thy might; I know young bloods look for a time of rest.

lines.speaker: lucius
lines.text: I have slept, my lord, already.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: It was well done; and thou shalt sleep again; I will not hold thee long: if I do live, I will be good to thee. This is a sleepy tune. O murderous slumber, Lay'st thou thy leaden mace upon my boy, That plays thee music? Gentle knave, good night; I will not do thee so much wrong to wake thee: If thou dost nod, thou break'st thy instrument; I'll take it from thee; and, good boy, good night. Let me see, let me see; is not the leaf turn'd down Where I left reading? Here it is, I think. How ill this taper burns! Ha! who comes here? I think it is the weakness of mine eyes That shapes this monstrous apparition. It comes upon me. Art thou any thing? Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil, That makest my blood cold and my hair to stare? Speak to me what thou art.
Music, and a song
Enter the Ghost of CAESAR

lines.speaker: ghost
lines.text: Thy evil spirit, Brutus.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Why comest thou?

lines.speaker: ghost
lines.text: To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Well; then I shall see thee again?

lines.speaker: ghost
lines.text: Ay, at Philippi.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Why, I will see thee at Philippi, then. Now I have taken heart thou vanishest: Ill spirit, I would hold more talk with thee. Boy, Lucius! Varro! Claudius! Sirs, awake! Claudius!
Exit Ghost

lines.speaker: lucius
lines.text: The strings, my lord, are false.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: He thinks he still is at his instrument. Lucius, awake!

lines.speaker: lucius
lines.text: My lord?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Didst thou dream, Lucius, that thou so criedst out?

lines.speaker: lucius
lines.text: My lord, I do not know that I did cry.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Yes, that thou didst: didst thou see any thing?

lines.speaker: lucius
lines.text: Nothing, my lord.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Sleep again, Lucius. Sirrah Claudius! Fellow thou, awake!
To VARRO

lines.speaker: varro
lines.text: My lord?

lines.speaker: claudius
lines.text: My lord?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Why did you so cry out, sirs, in your sleep?

lines.speaker: claudius
lines.text: Did we, my lord?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Ay: saw you any thing?

lines.speaker: varro
lines.text: No, my lord, I saw nothing.

lines.speaker: claudius
lines.text: Nor I, my lord.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Go and commend me to my brother Cassius; Bid him set on his powers betimes before, And we will follow.

lines.speaker: claudius
lines.text: It shall be done, my lord.
Exeunt
